item.title: Strong and weak factor assumptions
item.description: Strong and weak factor assumptions In this section, we briefly go over the strong and weak factor assumptions. Assuming factors $F_{t}$ and noise $e_{t}$ are uncorrelated and have zero mean, and normalization $\mathbb{E}(F_{t}F_{t}^{'}) = I_{r}$ for identification, then the population covariance matrix of the factor model (1) can be expressed as \begin{equation} \Sigma_{Y} = LL^{'} + \Sigma_{e}, \quad \quad \quad (2) \end{equation} where $\Sigma_{Y}$ and $\Sigma_{e}$ are the $N \times N$ population covariance matrix of $Y_{t}$ and $e_{t}$, respectively.
